Key Arguments: The bill threatens freedom of opinion and speech by allowing ACMA to censor opinions not deemed factual.
Differing ideological, religious, and medical beliefs could be suppressed.
The government should not be exempt from censorship and should be held to higher standards of factual accuracy.
The bill undermines media balance by centralizing truth determination with ACMA, removing individual decision-making.
The bill violates privacy by allowing ACMA to retain documents and create records without consent.
Notable Quotes: This bill would allow censorship to be inflicted upon any opinion that is not 'factual' in the eyes of the ACMA organisation.
The harm of the bill extends to balance in media.
This proposed bill also further violates the privacy of Australians.
